content.description: Route positioned to the left of Captain Crambowl. It offers a continuous flow for a great climbing on the grade. With a little bit of spicy tech moves on a slightly kicked out section between 3rd and 5th bolt. 9 bolts will take you to the chains.
content.location: It is located to the left of a prominent flake. As of summer 2019 it would be the 5th route on the left wall (L to R)

content.description: Last 20 feet are solid for the grade, thoughtful jug haul.
content.location: 9th bolted climb from the left, on the right side of the wall.

content.description: Climb left of a faint grey streak, passing a cluster of hanging green plants on the left, pull a small bulge and angle right to the belay on a nice ledge.
Last 20 feet are solid at the grade but with plenty of hands/feet.  Easier than the route immediate to its left.
content.location: 10th bolted climb from the left, on the right side of the wall.

content.description: Great technical flow for the grade. Start immediately to the left of the alcove. If desired to increase the grade, start with a bouldery move from within the alcove making a strenuous reachy move to the crimp below the first bolt.
content.location: Look for the bolt hanger above obvious alcove.

content.description: You'll spend about as much time clipping bolts as you will making moves.
content.location: 8th bolted climb from the left, on the right side of the wall. Climbs a left leaning ramp feature then ends abruptly.  VERY well bolted, likely intended as an introductory lead climb.

content.protection: 80 meter cord mandatory. 15 draws. Bring one or two longer slings for a couple of the bolts on traverses etc.
content.location: Start off of a boulder against the North Face (see topo), look for a line of stainless bolts above you leading up and through a 3 ft roof.

content.description: This is a great new route on the Universal Wall. Like most multipitch climbs on Mt Charleston, it is scrappy and chossy at times (bring helmets), but it is a fun adventure and the two crux pitches are incredible (subjective star ratings assigned to each pitch below).*P1 (80’, 5.10a, 8x Bolts): Climb chert ladder to belay stance on block in recess. Link easily with the next pitch if you can manage rope drag and conserve draws.*P2 (100’, 5.10b, 7x Bolts): Continue up chert ladder to bolted anchors on long ledge. Move belay 20’ right to end of ledge.**P3 (100’, 5.11a, 8x Bolts): Climb loose corner to difficult final moves to good belay ledge. Link easily with the next pitch if you can manage rope drag and conserve draws.**P4 (60’, 5.11a, 6x Bolts): Climb right-facing flakes to good ledge.***P5 (100’, 5.12a, 14x Bolts): Climb right-facing corner to roof. Sustained climbing leads through bulge and slab crux to high roof and awkward corner. Belay at hanging stance.****P6 (60’, 5.12c, 8x Bolts): Work rightwards through slabby crux and then up to stance. A second difficult slab crux guards passage to a good belay ledge. *P7 (90’, 5.10a, ?x Bolts): Climb gray wall towards two large trees. Work up ledges and left to a belay. **P8 (120’, 5.10d, ?x Bolts): Climb a long, grey streak with chert and flowstone holds to stance belay at top of wall.Descent: Rap the route EXCEPT for P3. Instead, rap down the wall left of the P3 corner to the anchor directly above P2 (the one you reach before moving the belay across the ledge).
content.location: Begin from three stone benches at left side of the Universal Wall.

content.description: 6 bolts lead to a 2 bolt anchor.   The first bolt is quite high.

climbs.name: Captain's Table
climbs.fa: Dan Briley, Mark Quinn, Mike Klinger 1993

content.description:
Myself, Mark, and Mike took turns leading this, placing one bolt each on the FA. Later Thomas Beck removed these and retro-bolted it with a few more. 

  Climb out the right side of an alcove then angle left and up through perfect washboard horizontal edges to an anchor.
content.location: At the top of the approach drainage on the left side is a moraine-like feature. Start on the right side of an alcove across from this.

climbs.name: Captain Crumbowl
climbs.fa: Dan Briley, Jason Astuto, et al. 1993

content.description:
I put his route up in summer of ’93 with Jason Astuto, Bart Dinsman, Mark Quinn, Mike Klinger, Gorge Smith et al. Sometime later Thomas Beck added eight more bolts and a belay on the first pitch.  

  Pitch 1, 5.9- Climb a flake with beautiful washboard holds until it ends at about 50’, continue up past a bulge to ledge with an anchor in hollow rock. Go up more washboard holds, passing a small roof on the left and aim for the shallow slot left of the dihedral. Belay on a nice ledge made of stacked blocks with a couple bolts in solid rock but wonky positions.   Pitch 2, 5.9- Step right for 10’ and go up steep rock between bulges. At the fourth bolt traverse hard right, staying below the whiter rotten rock, aiming for a short, thin, and dark crack about 80’ away where the cliff bends. Get gear in this crack, go around the corner and up easier rock to a small overhang. Belay above the overhang on a small stance on the left side go the huge cleft in the middle of the wall.   Pitch 3, 5.10c/d Climb steep rock straight up to thin ledge below the big roof. Follow the ledge right to where the roof is smaller and not as steep. Use a long runners on the bolts across the ledge or you’ll have big time rope drag. Belay on a nice small ledge above the roof.   Pitch 4, 5.8 Climb left and up easy terrain to a dihedral that ends at a big ledge. Continue on the face to the right and up to the huge ledge with the pine trees that runs across the top of the cliff. 

  Descent: Rappel, with two ropes, the last two pitches, then from the top of pitch two, a short rappel straight down to an anchor at the bottom of the large cleft in the middle of the wall. A long rap drops you on a wide section of the long ledge that runs across the bottom of the wall then one more rap to the ground from here.
content.protection: Bolts, single rack of cams from TCUs to a #3, stoppers.
content.location: On the left side of the Universal Wall are two large overhanging sections of white rock with a right-leaning gray swath between. This climb follows this gray swath. Start under a long thin flake about 40' right of an alcove at the base.

content.description: Good 5.8 face leads to one tricky move just before the anchors.
content.location: Directly between Captain Crumbowl's corner on the right and the alcove to the left.  Clean face full of chert holds.

content.description: Easy climbing to the high first and second bolts, followed by more engaging moves above, characterized by tucking left at each overhanging section. It's slightly easier than the 5.6 to the left....making it a solid 5.7.
content.location: Just right of Swallowtail's Delight, next to a pretty blue patch of rock.

content.description: The left side of the aptly named Universal Wall is a wide expanse of mostly beautifully solid rock overlaid with piles of choss and hollow flakes. There’s lots of good climbing along the base and a handful of multi-pitch lines. The rockfall potential is very serious here and anyone climbing up high will for sure be knocking rocks down, no matter how careful they are. Don’t climb under parties up on the wall! My friends and I dubbed this the Crumbowl Wall because of the constant rain of rocks whenever we were climbing here.
